intro: Sicana excisa, commonly known as the narrow-leaf Sicana, is a herbaceous plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Sicana excisa is adapted to dry conditions, with a deep root system that allows it to survive in poor soils. It is often found in rocky areas and is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological role.
